reasoning:
The critique targets a specific but nontrivial support pillar in §3.3: the claim that (otherwise attractive) bounded difference-making views with separate aggregation are still very fussy because even ~1/10^22 “bad” prevents a mostly-great future. If that sub-argument fails, the paper loses one route to “most plausible bounded views are fussy,” but the broader “no easy eutopia” conclusion still has substantial independent support (unbounded/approximately-linear arguments, multiplicative fragility in §2, and other bounded-view considerations). Hence moderate centrality.

On strength: it correctly notes that the 10^22 illustration relies on an implicit mapping from ‘resource share used badly’ to a large fraction of the disvalue bound, and that alternative separate-aggregation functional forms (e.g., strongly intensity-sensitive badness measures, or diminishing marginal disvalue over dispersed low-intensity bads) could block the inference to ‘almost no bads allowed.’ However, it under-specifies what counts as “plausible” here and doesn’t engage the paper’s setup where the upper bound is calibrated so common-sense utopia is already ~50% of the goods-bound; depending on that calibration, many “diminishing” forms may either reintroduce fussiness elsewhere or make the bound so high that the view becomes approximately linear (which the paper argues is also fussy). So it substantially pressures the example and demands more explicit functional-form/parameter robustness, but doesn’t clearly refute the underlying conclusion.

Relevance is fairly high because this is an internal, decision-relevant technical step in Forethought’s Better Futures agenda (how easygoing bounded views really are), rather than a generic objection to Tier-1 premises.
title: "The 10^22 Thought Experiment Implicitly Assumes Disvalue Geometry"
